speech.para: At the stroke of a pen the Howard government destroyed 450 highly skilled jobs at ASTAS in Avalon. It has also engineered some significant reductions in employment at Deakin University, and we have lost jobs in the Australian Taxation Office. We have lost the immigration department office and the customs office, and we have lost jobs in Telstra. These all add up to around 1,000 public sector jobs lost since the Howard government came to power.

If you take the Barwon south-western region, of which Geelong is a part, in the last two years we have lost in the region of 20,000 jobs. So it is with dismay that I observed, when the Howard government came to power, its proposals to scale down the east coast armaments complex which was scheduled to be built at Point Wilson in my electorate.

The particular facility was going to be some form of compensation, if you like, to the Geelong community for the destruction and the havoc that had been wrought on it by this particular government. It was with dismay that I saw that the government scaled down this particular project from $260 million, which was going to deliver us 600 jobs in the construction phase and provide over 200 jobs in the operational phase, to $70 million. And what Geelong is to get out of this is 60 jobs. Destroy 1,000 jobs in Geelongâthe Howard government has done thatâand in return we were to get a scaled down east coast armaments complex proposal that was to deliver 60. It is with some degree of concern that I have come across a release from the member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Nairn) who has called on the Joint Statutory Committee on Public Works to visit Eden on this particular proposalâand I note his presence in the chamber here today.

What an extraordinary situation that we have the public works committee going to Eden to look at situating the proposed east coast armaments complex there, when we have had a committee of inquiry conducted by the government, costing a lot of money, which has indicated that the most appropriate site for the east coast armaments complex is Point Wilson in my electorate. I find it an absolutely extraordinary situation that the chairman of that particular committee could trot his members down to the electorate of Eden-Monaro in the face of a report, done over two years and involving all the defence forces, which came to the conclusion that the most appropriate site for this particular facility was at Point Wilson in Geelong.

The Geelong community has been rolled over and trodden on by the Howard government. We have lost 1,000 jobs since this government came to power. We have one of the highest regional unemployment rates in this country and since the Howard government came to power we have lost 20,000 jobs in the Barwon south-western region. I would have thought that any government that had an ear or an eye for regional development would have grasped the opportunity to support a local community and situate the full east coast armaments complex in the Geelong region.

We do not want a scaled-down $70 million facsimile of the project. We want the full monty; we want the $260 million project that is going to deliver us 600 jobs, not the paltry 60 being doled out now by the Howard government. It is an absolute disgrace how this government has driven the boot into rural and regional communities around this nation. And it has done it without putting any sorts of adjustment packages in place to support those communities. I am demanding that this particular proposal, this idiotic proposal, be taken off the table and that that complex be located in my electorate. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI might respond to the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) on that subject at another time. I could also talk about the hundreds and hundreds of jobs lost in the timber industry in the south-east of my electorate under the government that he was part of over a number of years which just devastated an industry to keep some people in city areas happy. But that is not the reason I wanted to speak in this adjournment debate.

speech.para: I want to say something in relation to the ongoing and almost desperate situation that is occurring in many parts of my electorate due to the ongoing drought. On the Monaro in the February just gone I was able to announce exceptional circumstance assistance to a number of the farmers who are really going through an unbelievably bad time. This drought, not only in my electorate but in many parts of New South Wales, is probably one of the worst on record and the ramifications are starting to flow in areas that people just would not have believed.

The federal government was able to announce exceptional circumstance assistance to quite a number of people in that drought area. It gives some short-term help. It is over initially a 12-month period, then an additional 12-month period. It gives some interest rate subsidy. It allows people to access a health card and Austudy, where they normally would not be able to because of asset tests, and, in some circumstances, gives them an exceptional circumstance relief payment. That is good news. What they really need is rain and rain and rain, but that does help a little bit to get them over a number of difficult situations.

I hope the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) will be receiving next week a further report from the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council, RASAC, about an extended area which is, I believe, even worse than the area that has been declared to be in exceptional circumstances. I am getting phone calls constantly in my office as the drought is basically expanding.

One of the worst things that happened in the last couple of months was that the New South Wales government withdrew their drought freight subsidy to farmers who were sending stock away on agistment and those sorts of things. The timing of withdrawing that subsidy was just unbelievably bad. I cannot believe that they would do such a thing. I understand the long-term reasons for making these changes. There have been agreements between the New South Wales government and the federal governmentâ

talk.start.para: âFederal cutbacks to the state.

âIt is not federal cutbacks at all. That is absolute garbage. In relation to the ongoing situation with drought assistance, there have to be structural changes. We agree with that. But to pull off the subsidies in the middle of what is now being recognised as probably the worst drought on record in this area is just unbelievably heartless.

speech.para: I call on the New South Wales government to put those subsidies back in. I just could not believe the timing. The minister said at the time, `It is all because of structural adjustments for drought and agreements from 1992,' but he did it when his own department were supporting very strongly the assistance that we are giving through exceptional circumstances. Members of that department have been very helpful in that regard.

The extent of the drought I think is now really starting to hit home. It is not only the Monaro. Down on the coastal area as well, the dairying industry is now starting to see some difficulties and, if they do not get some rain that can give a little growth before winter comes on, they also will be in trouble. On top of that you can see it extending right up around the Canberra area and I am sure if visitors and members who come from elsewhere in Australia to Canberra to parliament go a little bit beyond the precincts of parliament, they will also see what is happening. On some of the hills you will see even native trees dying. When you start to see native trees dying because of a lack of water you really know that there is a problem.

talk.start.para: âIt is a very serious problem in Western Australia.

âIt is a major problem that is extending right throughout the south-east and I note the honourable member for Moore commenting that it is similar in Western Australia. I was talking with some people from New Zealand earlier today, and they said the same. (Time expired)

âI rise today to draw the parliament's attention to the potential crisis emerging over the issue of Cyprus. As the parliament would be aware, Cyprus has applied for admission into the European Union and European Union negotiations are occurring at the moment. The Turkish government is attempting to derail the Cypriot entry into the European Union and I hope that the EU negotiators judge the application on its merits. I think that, if that occurs, there is no doubt that Cyprus will be accepted as a full member of the EU.

speech.para: Turkey has responded to this by threatening to annex northern Cyprus into the Turkish state if the EU agrees to Cypriot membership. I think that that, whilst it should not be all that surprising, is an extremely dangerous and volatile move. In the northern part of Cyprus 37 per cent of the island is occupied by some 35,000 Turkish troops. The northern part of the island only survives on the basis of being propped up financially by the Ankara regime. They already share telecommunications facilities and currency with Turkey. The response of Rauf Denktash, the leader of the bogus regime in northern Cyprus, to reject the Cyprus government's offer to allow for Turkish Cypriot representation in the EU negotiations highlights the fact that they are not serious about a peaceful resolution to the Cypriot question.

This will be the 24th year since the invasion by the Turkish army. Once again we have a situation whereby Turkey is saying that they will annex, formally and illegally, the northern part of Cyprus. That will then undoubtedly lead to the potential for war in the Mediterranean. That would be a disaster, most importantly, for the Cypriot people whether they be of Turkish or Greek origin. I visited Cyprus on a delegation with the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) and the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) some 18 months ago. What is clear is that the Cypriot people, regardless of their origin, do want a peaceful resolution to this crisis.

If it is the case that in my electorate of Grayndler and in other parts of AustraliaâI note that the member for Moore (Mr Filing) is here today and he is a great friend of the Cypriot peopleâwe see Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots living next to each other in harmony as part of our multicultural society, it should surely be possible for a bi-communal solution to the Cypriot question. But what we have is intransigence on the part of the Denktash regime and their masters in Ankara; bullying and threats of coercion against the European Union; and a situation wherein the ethnic cleansing that occurred after the 1974 invasion of Cyprus continues to be the fundamental basis of that regime. That is something that all Australians who support multiculturalism should find unacceptable. It is certainly something that the international communityâwhich, with the exception of Turkey, refuses to recognise the Denktash regime, as it is a renegade regimeâshould be acting on to ensure that there is a peaceful solution to the Cyprus question, and it should be rejecting the bullying by Turkey over Cyprus's entry into the European Union.

talk.start.para: âDeputy Speaker Jenkins, as you and other members would know, under the former government, telecommunications infrastructure was virtually a question of open slather, and we had mobile phone towers popping up like loathsome toadstools all over the cities of Australia. We had overhead cable being strung like spaghetti in the garden suburbs of our great cities.

speech.para: I am pleased to say that last year the current government changed the law. As of 1 July 1997, major items of telecommunications infrastructure, such as mobile phone towers and overhead cabling, could go ahead only with the consent of local governments or state governments. Of the changes brought in by the government, it is one of which I am most personally proud. In addition, last year, the government announced the spending of more than $4 million to study the possible health effects of this type of electromagnetic radiation on nearby residents.

There is, however, an ongoing problem in my electorate. Next week, Telstra will be turning on a mobile phone base station at Dalwood in Seaforth. No work substantially commenced before 1 July last year. There has been no agreement from Manly council. When Telstra indicated that they were going ahead, Manly council took them to court. Unfortunately, in the first instance, Manly council lost in the New South Wales Land and Environment Courtâwhich I am afraid has taken a very liberal and, one may even say, idiosyncratic view as to what counts as commencement. My understanding is that the current position of the New South Wales Land and Environment Court is that mere design work constitutes the commencement of these stations.

I want to make three points. The first point is that Manly council is considering an appeal, as I understand the situation, and it would be most unwise of Telstra to go ahead with the switching on of the base station before that appeal has been decided. The second point is that Telstra is a fine Australian companyâit is obviously our telecommunications flagshipâbut, in that position, it does have very special corporate responsibilities. It is still in two-thirds public ownership and even after it passes into private ownership, because of its semi-monopolistic nature, it will operate under special conditions. Telstra, of all companies, cannot afford to act like a corporate bully. I believe that Telstra should sit down with Manly council and enter into further negotiations, in the spirit of the law introduced by this government.

The third point I would like to make is that, plainly, some telecommunications companiesâperhaps in anticipation of the government's law last yearâhave been pulling swifties with their local communities. They have put up a sign here, they have turned a sod there and they have begun design work somewhere else. Quite frankly, this should not be enough for work on these installations to go ahead without proper local or state approval. I will be asking Senator Alston to consider changing this legislation, in order to prohibit the erection of these facilities without council consent, unless they were substantially commenced before 1 July 1997.

I notice that I have one minute left and so I would like to draw the attention of the committee to some statements made by the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) in his new book which was, as we know, a long instruction manual for his colleagues, particularly the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley).
I am sure members opposite will be delighted to know that the member for Werriwa says on page 104 of his new book:
The quest for full employment has actually been achievedâ
in this country, which is an interesting position for a member of the Labor Party to adopt. He also says:
. . . high unemployment is not a problem across the macro economy.
This is an extremely interesting position for any member of parliament in this place to have, given that unemployment is still over eight per cent.

The truth is the Leader of the Opposition has a big problem with the member for Werriwa. The member for Werriwa thinks he is running policy; he thinks he is running the opposition. He needs to be disciplined. He needs to decide what political party he wants to join because, quite frankly, he is too right wing for the Labor Party.

talk.start.para: âWe saw recently the extraordinary spectacle of the state premiers, most of whom come from the coalition parties, walking out at the Premiers Conference following their obvious belief that they were getting nowhere with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in negotiating what they consider to be a satisfactory regime for the provision of health care facilities in the state infrastructures.

speech.para: I might add that I have issued an enormous number of press releases in relation to health problems in my own electorate, particularly concerning the northern suburbs, the new developing areas. I have often come across the situation where I have had the state minister blaming Canberraâhe says that Canberra is not giving him an adequate amount of moneyâand when I ask the Prime Minister he will say, `There is no problem. In fact, Western Australia is doing very well out of its arrangements with the Commonwealth.' It is an interesting situation because whenever I have tried to raise these issues on behalf of my constituents, as I am obliged to do as their representative, I have found that there is duck shoving between the two levels of government. That is very unfortunate, given the problems we have.

My electorate is in a key location in the city of Perth. It spans a coastal development corridor for expansion of the city northwards and it is experiencing a growth rate of around 24 per cent per annum in some places. People are drawn to the area by the opportunity to build or buy new homes, and raise families, and they can look forward to a relatively high standard of living. However, their dreams are beginning to unravel as the state government finds it increasingly difficult to provide from its own revenue sources the necessary range of services to foster and support this growth.

This is something I have spoken on a number of occasionsâthe vertical fiscal imbalance in the Commonwealth-state fiscal arrangementsâand it is something that the incoming coalition government promised to address. Certainly, when I was a member of the Liberal Party I was told it was going to be addressed when we got into government. Now that I am an Independent member I have found that no change has been made and that it is not even mooted to be discussed by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) as part of taxation reform measures.

talk.start.para: âYes, it is.

âNo, it is not. Essential services in this region are reaching a crisis point. Health care, in particular, is an area which cannot be ignored. Let me make a list of some of the problems. There is a lack of out of hours health care. Emergencies are being transferred to the city, which adds an extra 20 minutes travel and puts people at greater risk. There is a lack of beds for care, and people are being sent home in an inappropriate state of health to make way for other patients.

speech.para: I had a particular case of a frail, elderly patient who was sent back to one of my local retirement estates with tubes still attached to her. This is an extraordinary situation. No out of hours medical care was available at that particular facility. When I went to the state minister and complained about that I was told by him there was nothing he could do and he suggested I negotiate with local medical practitioners to see if any of them would provide the service.

There are ambulance problems faced by seriously ill people. There is a lack of locum services, and inadequate support for or access to mental health services in my area. The state promised to improve the situation based on the planned hospital at Joondalup, but that has been dogged by problems, especially revenue shortages. The most recent problem, as recently as last week, was the announcement by the hospital chief executive at Joondalup, Ian MacDonald, that all elective surgery was cancelled from 6 April to 1 May because of underfunding by the state government.

I cannot express enough disgust at this particular decision. We always know that elective surgery is one of those definitions which is very nebulous. It makes it extraordinarily difficult for my constituents, in particular, considering that this hospital is a privatised hospital. One of the things that I tried to achieve, when the matter was originally being plannedâand as a consequence of some of the shortfalls in its operationsâwas to have a local board of management appointed with true provision for accountability. Unfortunately, they chose instead to have an advisory board, which means not much at all, and the situation is that there is no direct accountability for the local community other than via their local state members, who presumably toe the party line and say nothing if they are put on the spot by their respective parties.

In conclusion, we have a situation which is unacceptable. The health care scenario in my electorate is substandard and needs to be radically addressed. It needs to be urgently sorted out. I might add that, when my constituents saw the state premiers walking out on the Prime Ministerâtaking their cricket bats and going homeâat the Premiers Conference and they saw the Prime Minister stonewalling for his own particular reasons, I am sure they, like many other people in this country, wondered how and why our system of governance had got into this state, and they scratched their heads and thought, `Well, if this is the way government is going under our two-party system, there also need to be changes to that'. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âAt no time did I doubt the success of this government's work for the dole program, but in my wildest dreams I did not expect such positive results within the first few weeks. I must admit that I am fortunate that the two organisations in my electorate to be awarded the work for the dole projects are run by remarkably dedicated and motivated people. One is run by Craig Belmanno of Norman Park. Craig was a finalist in the Young Australian of the Year in 1997. A dedicated environmentalist, he established the Moreton Bay Marine Association and galvanised local environmentalists to his excellent cause. He now has more than 120 young work for the dole volunteers who have discovered what it is like to work with community groups on environmental projects. The Moreton Bay Marine Association work for the dole project is revegetating and cleaning up the creeks and rivers which run into Moreton Bay, including Bulimba Creek in my electorate, an important catchment for the city of Brisbane.

speech.para: Craig Belmanno reported to me earlier this week that, since he started his work for the dole scheme in December, one in five of his volunteers have left to take up a full-time job. While this situation interrupts his work flow, he said, `It is absolutely beautiful to see.' Craig reinforces the view of this government that, if you give a person a goal, a reason to get up every morning, their life is greatly enhanced.

The second work for the dole project in my electorate is run by the South East Training Centre, formerly skillshare, at Coorparoo. Shane Cowan, the manager, has been involved in the training and job placement of long-term unemployed in my electorate for the past eight years. He knows his job and he has a good rapport with employers in the district. The suburbs that the South East Training Centre service, particularly within Griffith, are made up of a broad mix of people from many different parts of the world. As English is not the first language of many of the residents, employment options have been limited.

Shane has reported to me this week that his work for the dole participants have responded to his programs with enthusiasm, and all the participants in my electorate on both programs have been volunteers. One of Shane Cowan's work for the dole projects has been the restoration of the Cannon Hill School of Arts building. Of his team, already 11 young people have found full-time jobs. Others have been offered traineeships and a handful have been motivated into developing business plans to set up their own small business.

When I visited Cannon Hill School of Arts recently, I met with the team of eight working with Shane and their supervisor. They were restoring the original timber windows, painting walls, repairing the roof and the floor and generally giving this wonderful old community hall a much needed new lease of life. On the way, they have been learning to work as a team and, more importantly, discovering that their services are needed and appreciated by the community.

All the young people working on that day said that they were enjoying being part of the work for the dole project. The tradespeople of Cannon Hill and surrounding suburbs have also responded to this work for the dole with vigour and support. They have assisted with tools, equipment, advice and encouragement. Both organisations tell me that their work for the dole project has given everyone involved a new focus. Employers are attracted to the fact that the program reveals the determination of some of the young participants to get a job.

The Labor Party has bagged this program from the day it was announced, not because they thought it would not work, but because they simply did not want it to work. They do not want to see any reforms introduced by this government to improve the lives of the unemployed. The opposition are not interested in reform; they are only interested in power at any price. Work for the dole is working and I have proof of it in my electorate, in these projects alone.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to comments made by Dr M.K. McIntosh, then Deputy Secretary, Acquisition and Logistics, Department of Defence, to a Senate Estimates Committee on 10 October 1989 (Senate Estimates Committee Hansard, 10 October 1989, page 333) about the need for the Government to approve relocating the construction of modules for the Anzac Ships Project.
(2) Does the relocation of the construction of modules for the Anzac Ships Project require Government approval.

(3) Did he approve the relocation of the construction of a module by Tenix Defence Systems for frigates Nos. 6 to 10 from the Hunter region to New Zealand; if so, (a) when and (b) were members of parliament from the Hunter region advised; if so, in each case, when.
(4) When is New Zealand required to decide if it will accept an option to extend its order for Anzac ships.
(5) Did he discuss the relocation referred to in part (3) with the New Zealand Minister for Defence; if so (a) when and (b) was it within the context of New Zealand ordering additional ships.
(6) Has an agreement been reached between the Australian and New Zealand Governments for New Zealand to acquire additional Anzac ships.
(7) Was the relocation of module construction discussed with the Prime Minister of New Zealand during her visit in early 1998.

(8) Has the New Zealand Prime Minister or Minister for Defence given assurances regarding the extension of New Zealand's order for Anzac ships; if so, were they given in the context of increasing contract expenditure in New Zealand.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) and (3) (a) and (b) There is no requirement for Government or Ministerial approval for changes to sub-contracting arrangements that are made within the terms of the ANZAC Ship Contract. However, the ANZAC Ship Contract requires the contractor to notify the Department of Defence of changes of sub-contractors and details of work being performed by sub-contractors, and this includes the relocation of the construction of modules for the ANZAC Ship Project. The Department cannot unreasonably withhold its approval of the change if there is a valid commercial reason for the change and the proposed change does not breach the contracted balance of work between Australian and New Zealand industry.

(4) There was a fully priced contract option for two additional ANZAC Ships for New Zealand which had to be exercised by November 1997. New Zealand did not exercise this option. There is also an unpriced contract option for an additional two ships for New Zealand which remains open for the term of the Contract.

(6) There is no agreement between the Australian and New Zealand Governments regarding the purchase of additional ANZAC Ships, other than the ANZAC Ship Contract and the Treaty between Australia and New Zealand relating to the purchase of ANZAC Ships. These agreements were entered into in 1989.

(8) The New Zealand Government has given no assurances that it will purchase additional ANZAC Ships. If additional ANZAC Ships are ordered by New Zealand within the context of both the ANZAC Ship Contract and Treaty, then the workshare would need to be consistent with the principles of these documents. New Zealand could enter into a separate commercial arrangement with Tenix Defence Systems for further ANZAC ships. Such an arrangement would be outside the terms of the extant Contract and Treaty and would therefore not be bound by the existing workshare arrangements.
